data.title: News Archives for Latest
data.meta_description: Latest News on Business, Finance and Markets from Pakistan
data.text:
Iraqi parliamentarians elect speaker in shadow of jail attack

Iraq's new parliament elected a Sunni Muslim speaker Sunday, ending two months of bitter sectarian wrangling, as an insurgent assault on a US-run jail wounded 44 US soldiers and 12 detainees. MPs chose Sunni Arab Hajem al-Hassani as speaker and Shiite Hus

Kyrgyz leader Akayev agrees to resign

Kyrgyzstan's deposed president Askar Akayev agreed to formally resign on Sunday in a move welcomed by the Central Asian state's post-coup government as key to cementing the opposition's seizure of power. Akayev made the announcement at a brief news confer

Charles to wed on Friday

The wedding of Britain's Prince Charles to Camilla Parker Bowles, already hit by several glitches, will go ahead on Friday even if it clashes with the funeral of Pope John Paul, a spokeswoman said on Sunday. Clarence House said the date of April 8 had bee

World mourns Pope as pilgrims gather in homage

Pope John Paul's body was displayed to the world on Sunday and his words echoed across St. Peter's Square as faithful mourned the Pole who helped topple Communism in Europe but left a divided Church. Streams of pilgrims converged on Rome in a spontaneous

Muslims hail Pope's bridge-building with Islam

Many Muslims round the world on Sunday praised Pope John Paul for having pressed to build bridges with Islam and said his death had cost both faiths a campaigner for peace and justice. The Pope led a campaign over the past two decades to help turn stand-o

Pope's reign full of contradictions, critics say

As world leaders hailed Pope John Paul as a force for peace, Catholic reformers critical of his traditionalist stand on Church dogmas took issue with his 26-year papacy, which ended with his death on Saturday. Supporters credited the Polish Pontiff with p

Edgy US investors eye Greenspan and oil

A nervous US stock market fretting over high oil prices and inflation will watch Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan this week for any unexpected hints on the pace of future interest-rate rises. After a disappointing first quarter when the blue chip D

South Korean shares to rise slightly

South Korean share prices are expected to rise slightly this week with sentiment boosted by positive data and optimism over a long hoped for economic recovery, dealers said. They said the market should advance after foreign investors finally moved to the

Malaysian shares may suffer losses

Malaysian share prices could suffer more losses, with trading likely to be lacklustre and fragmented after falling 0.85 percent this week, analysts said. "The market is expected to stay on its downward bias consolidation path," said Victor Wan, senior ana

Bangladesh interbank foreign exchange and interest rates

Interbank buy/sell rates for the taka against the dollar on Sunday: 63.20/63.70 (previous 63.20/63.70). Call Money Rates: 6.0-15.0 percent (previous 4.0-14.0 percent).

UK Investors look to BoE interest rate decision

The London stock market will probably focus this week on the Bank of England's interest rate decision in a period bereft of much corporate news, analysts said. The FTSE 100 index of leading London shares closed at 4,914.0 points on Friday, down 8.5 points

Indian stocks seen firm as traders watch world markets

Indian shares are expected to trade firm this week as investors watch steadily rising world markets and as domestic companies gear up to announce their quarterly earnings, dealers said. The benchmark Bombay Stock Exchange index closed Friday at 6,605.04,

Hong Kong shares to trade in narrow range on oil and rate concerns

Hong Kong share prices are likely to trade in a narrow range this week as prevailing concerns over interest rates and high oil prices weigh on sentiment, dealers said. They noted that investors were cautious ahead of the release later Friday of March unem

Taiwan shares rangebound this week

Taiwan share prices are expected to trade within a narrow 200-points range this week as investors assess corporate first quarter results in the hope of getting a better lead on the economic outlook, dealers said. Much too will depend on the US March emplo

Thai market likely to post gains

The Thai stock market was expected to post limited gains this week ahead as pressured by high oil prices and a weakening Thai baht, analysts said. "I think the index could continue to gain in the first few days of the week but then I see profit-taking by

Asian currencies lower amid worries over US interest rates

The yen and Australian dollar closed lower over the past week as the prospect of further US interest rate hikes continued to weigh heavily on currencies around the region.

Tokyo shares under pressure on gloomy economic outlook

Japanese stocks are expected to remain under pressure this week as the outlook for the world's second-largest economy becomes more uncertain amid growing concerns over rising oil prices, dealers said. Optimism over Japan's swift recovery from a mild reces

OPTD results help Cairo bourse higher

Strong 2004 results from Orascom Projects and Touristic and Development helped the Egyptian stock market to recover from recent losses on Sunday, traders said. The benchmark Hermes index, which last month touched a record high above 40,000, climbed 1.4 pe

Kuwaiti stocks top 8,000 for first time ever

Kuwait's main share index edged up on Sunday to top 8,000 points for the first time in its history amid a renewed surge in world oil prices and expectations of companies reporting strong first-quarter profits. The Kuwait Stock Exchange index grouping 130

Philippines shares may weaken

Philippines share prices may weaken this week as the modest upturn of recent days runs its course and the market returns to the downward trend which took if off 5-year highs over the past few weeks, dealers said. They said there are considerable concerns

LG and Matsushita to settle plasma dispute

The world's No 1 and 3 suppliers of plasma panels, the key component in flat-screen televisions, have agreed to settle their dispute over plasma display technology, a newspaper said on April 02. South Korea's LG Electronics Inc and Japan's Matsushita Elec

IAC to be selective buyer after Ask Jeeves

IAC/InterActiveCorp, fresh off announcing its $1.85 billion offer for Web search provider Ask Jeeves Inc, will look at other possible acquisitions as they arise but will be very selective, the company's chief financial officer said on March 30. Thomas McI

Royal Bank of Canada to open insurance outlets

Royal Bank of Canada, the country's biggest bank, plans to open insurance outlets adjacent to several bank branches in an experiment to see if it can generate traffic between its insurance and bank businesses. Insurance is one of Royal's fastest growing b

Malaysian stock exchange looks to return cash pile

Malaysia's newly listed stock exchange is looking to return some of its 860 million ringgit ($226 million) cash pile to shareholders, saying it only needs up to 60 percent of that to run the business. "This money is more than what we need," Bursa Malaysia

Fortum seeks up to 500 million euros from Neste IPO

Finnish energy group Fortum aims to raise up to 500 million euros ($650 million) from the sale of shares in Neste Oil, seeking to tap sky-high oil prices in Helsinki's biggest new listing in years. Fortum set a price range on Tuesday of 11 to 13 euros per

Indian software testing moves from boredom to boom

Testing software to ferret out bugs that drive consumers crazy was once seen as dull and dreary work to be shunned by brainy technology experts. But the need to ensure electronic products' quality has spawned the latest hiring boom in the $16 billion outs

Iraqi bourse looks to security as much as securities

London Stock Exchange stalks China IPOs

The London Stock Exchange has spent the last five months trying to win Chinese listings, but market watchers say the bourse faces a tough challenge as mainland companies are increasingly less reliant on foreign cash. The LSE, subject of a take-over battle

Mobile carriers seek cheaper anti-piracy software

A powerful group of mobile telecoms operators on Friday called for lower prices for essential anti-piracy systems, warning that high royalty payments may stifle the markets for digital music and video. The mobile phone industry's Open Mobile Alliance (OMA

European IT firms log in to India to raise profits

European information technology service firms are turning more and more to India in a bid to cut costs, raise profits and ward off an emerging threat from Indian rivals on their own turf. Capgemini, Atos Origin, Xansa and LogicaCMG are among IT firms hiri

Taiwan government stymied by UMC China investment

IBM sees Cell chip for industry

IBM is taking the highly anticipated Cell chip technology at the heart of the future Sony PlayStation and offering to help customers design it into a far wider range of electronics, from aerospace to military to medical products, the company said on Wedne

Aixtron sees difficult business climate in 2005

German semiconductor equipment maker Aixtron expects a difficult business climate this year and cannot yet give a more detailed forecast, it said in a statement on Thursday. The company, which earlier this month completed the 75 million euro ($97 million)

Mitsubishi Electric cellphone ops in black in 2005-06

Japan's Mitsubishi Electric Corp said on Friday its loss-making cellphone business would likely turn profitable in the business year just started, helped by cost costs and smaller restructuring-related expenses. Mitsubishi Electric President Tamotsu Nomak

Microsoft Corp will release an update to its Windows Server software for networked computers that will include new security enhancements, the world's largest software maker said on Wednesday. The update, called Windows Server 2003 Service Pack 1, was desi

New Intel CEO says tax reformers must look abroad

The United States faces a losing battle for new semiconductor factories if it does not compete against other countries with tax incentives, Intel Corp President Paul Otellini told a presidential advisory panel on tax reform on Thursday. "The money is shif

PC makers to offer full Windows version in Europe

The world's two largest PC makers said on Friday that they expect mostly to sell machines with full version of Windows in Europe despite a European antitrust order forcing Microsoft Corp to offer a stripped-down version of its flagship operating system. A

HEALTH UPDATE: special acupuncture lowers blood pressure

A specialised acupuncture treatment that uses low levels of electrical stimulation can lower blood pressure dramatically in rats, US researchers reported on Monday (21 March). "This study suggests that acupuncture can be an excellent complement to other m

HEALTH UPDATE: scientists find arthritis-causing enzyme

Australian scientists have identified an enzyme that destroys cartilage in mice and believe the find may lead to new drugs which stop cartilage joint deterioration and painful arthritis in humans. "We consider this to be a significant advance because unti

HEALTH UPDATE: mechanism for strengthening muscles discovered

Researchers have discovered a mechanism of biochemical signals that helps build muscle strength, which they say could help treat muscle-wasting diseases and heart failure, said a study published Thursday (31 March). The European researchers, led by Stepha

HEALTH UPDATE: new compound may prevent allergies

A new chemical compound, part-cat and part-human, may provide an end to misery-making cat allergies, US researchers reported on Sunday (27 March). And they said their approach in creating the compound may work against more dangerous allergies, such as dea

World's resources being used up, biggest-ever study warns

Sixty percent of the world's resources are being degraded or used up, with "substantial and largely irreversible" loss of biodiversity set to worsen over the next 50 years, the biggest environmental study ever undertaken warned on Wednesday (30 March). Th

Raw food vegetarian thin but healthy

People on strict raw food vegetarian diets are thin but healthy, US researchers reported on Monday (28 March). Although nutritionists and the food industry have warned that a diet without dairy foods can lead to the bone-thinning disease osteoporosis, the

Computers no cure-all for medical errors

Using computers to prescribe drugs has helped doctors curb dangerous errors caused by messy handwriting and bureaucratic mishaps, but the technology can create its share of mistakes, a study said on Tuesday. In some cases, fragmented computer displays res

Scientists puzzled why earthquake did not produce destructive tsunami

Tsunami experts could not understand why Monday's forceful earthquake off Indonesia failed to produce massive waves similar to those generated by the December 26 quake that killed at least 174,000 people in the same region. A magnitude 8.7 quake shook Ind

US plans to catalogue cancer genome

US medical officials are considering a project to map the genetic anomalies linked to cancer in a new effort to combat the disease, the New York Times reported on Monday (28 March). The Human Cancer Genome Project will be more ambitious than that undertak

Asia-Pacific region hard hit by natural disasters: UN

The Asia-Pacific region has accounted for four out of every five global victims of natural disasters for the past century and remains highly vulnerable, a UN report said on Tuesday (29 March). The release of the report at a conference of regional environm

Dandruff, fur and pollen affect atmosphere

Bits of pollen, leaf fragments and even dandruff from people and animals make up a significant portion of dusty stuff in the atmosphere but have been ignored by climate modelers, German researchers said on Thursday (31 March). Their painstaking, 15-year m

Six diseases cause 73 percent of child deaths: WHO

Six mainly preventable diseases account for 73 percent of child deaths each year, the World Health Organisation said on Friday (25 March). Pneumonia accounts for 19 percent of the under-fives who die, followed by diarrhoea, pre-term delivery, malaria, blo

New genetically modified rice may reduce childhood blindness

Scientists in Britain have developed a strain of genetically modified rice which they say could reduce vitamin A deficiency and childhood blindness in developing countries, the BBC said on Monday (28 March). The biotechnology firm Syngenta's laboratories

Hong Kong a dumping ground for toxic hi-tech waste

Hong Kong is being used as a dumping ground for hi-tech waste from all over the world by traders illegally selling the harmful trash to China, Greenpeace said on Monday, (28 March). The environmental lobby group said it had found five sites in the souther

China and India seek co-operation in global oil quest

Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao visits India this week with the race between the world's two most populous nations to secure the energy they need to fuel their growing economies likely to be on the agenda. In volatile trouble spots from Sudan to Myanmar, both

ECB predicted to keep rates steady

The European Central Bank will leave eurozone interest rates unchanged for the 22nd straight month this Thursday, with a tightening move seen unlikely before the second half of the year, economists are predicting. In Britain the coming week is expected to

Audi agrees not to lay off German workers

The board of Volkswagen's premium car maker Audi and its workers council have agreed not to lay off any of the 45,000 workers at its German plants under a deal lasting until 2012, a German newspaper said. The Frankfurt Allgemeine Sonntagszeitung said that

HSBC mulling bid for Morgan Stanley

Is it a bubble? Experts debate surging US real estate prices

Is real estate another bubble ready to burst? Experts are cautiously watching the red-hot US housing market, but remain divided on the likelihood of a crash that could be a devastating economic blow. On a national level, home prices last year rose 8.3 per

South Korea battles charges of anti-foreign investor bias

The South Korean government is on the defensive against charges that Asia's third largest economy is hostile to foreign investors, forcing them to step through a minefield of arbitrary legislation. At the center of debate are new disclosure regulations in

Brussels set to forecast cloudy spring for EU economies

Myanmar dismays investors with ban on drilling onshore

Myanmar's energy-hungry neighbours have an eager eye on its large oil and gas reserves, but the ruling junta has dampened their enthusiasm by barring foreign firms from onshore exploration and production. The decision announced in March stumped energy exp

Germany gearing for reform, but jobs still a worry

There is a growing consensus among German lawmakers over how to get on with reforms aimed at reviving Europe's largest economy but the lack of flexibility in the country's troubled labour market remains a big worry. In an interview on Sunday, Economy Mini

Australia fiscal 2005 growth less than government forecast

Australia's economic growth will slow to 2 percent in fiscal 2005, hurt by a cooler housing market and inadequate transport and port facilities to move exports, a report showed on Monday. The forecast by Access Economics is sharply lower than the governme

Japanese firms take lead in sustainable development

Intel to spend $5 billion on chip plant upgrades

Intel Corp, the world's largest electronic chipmaker, plans to spend close to $5 billion this year on upgrading older plants to enable the production of smaller chips, its chief executive officer said on Sunday. Craig Barrett told reporters in Jerusalem t

Kim Clijsters's resurgence continued here Saturday as the former world number one from Belgium defeated second-seeded Wimbledon champion Maria Sharapova 6-3, 7-5 to claim the WTA title at Key Biscayne. As she did at Indian Wells, California, last week, Cl
